content: Hello @WG-async-foundations! It's time for our weekly meeting.
Go ahead and react with a :wave: to show you're here
Our agenda for this week is:

• Announcements
  • New issue triage
  • Discussion on progress/blockers around sprint bugs
Let's start with announcements.
I don't have much, does anyone else have anything to share?
In case anyone missed it, the Async Rust in 2022 post was published last week
That's great!
Is there anything else to announce?

Sounds like not, so we can move on:
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
Next up is triage.
We have two new issues
In the blog post I mentioned this meeting as a way to get involved. Maybe we should have a time for people who want to introduce themselves to do so
Ah, good idea!
We'll hold off on triage to give people a change to do introductions
(In the future we could combine with announcements)
(agreed, I'll update the standing agenda)

Thanks for the opportunity @tmandry . My name is Martin Ombura, been learning/working with Rust for 2 years now. Currently living in Cape Town, South Africa . Ive worked quite a bit with async rust more so with Web Servers and DBs, and have familiarized myself with the async book. However I'm definitely no expert but willing to learn and help wherever :pray:
Welcome, @Martin Ombura Jr., we're glad to have you!
yes, welcome :)

My name's Eric Holk. I live in the US West Coast. I was an early Rust contributor, then an observer for a few years, and now I'm back to being able to do Rust full time again. I lead the Async Polish goal, so if that's something you're interested in I can help you get started there.
I'll go ahead and move on with triage, but if anyone else wants to post intro blurbs feel free to interject.
Our triage issues are both pretty similar
Drop tracking misses variables consumed in let statements #93674
Drop tracking ignores borrows with projections #93648
The first one is a case where drop tracking is missing a case it should handle.
It should be an easy fix hopefully, but fortunately being less precise isn't a soundness issue, it just means we borrow too aggressively in a few cases.
The second one is worse, since it means we miss a capture that should be there. Unfortunately that leads to an ICE.
are these bugs in your PR, @eholk ?
On the bright side, I was going to be continuing to look at drop tracking ICEs this week, so this gives me a nice test case to work with.
(did we re-enable that PR?)
We didn't re-enable it, but the disabling PR took a few days to land
got it
These are both from the 2022-01-22 nightly, so that would have been before the disabling PR merged anyway.

Given that there are probably a few extra ICEs around drop tracking (the crater run on #93180 found ~750 of them, though hopefully they're not all unique), I'm wondering if it makes sense to make the drop tracking flag a proper feature flag, and then land the individual fixes separately, rather than trying to fix them all in one go?
that sounds reasonable
@eholk that makes sense to me
do you have a sense for whether those 750 cases consist of a few core bugs ?
(I'm not sure how you would know)
FYI: I added a flag to enable drop tracking in #93313.
Hopefully it won't take too long to stabilize, but I'm getting nervous having tests that are ignored.

tm said:

FYI: I added a flag to enable drop tracking in #93313.

Oh, awesome!
@tm - We should get someone to sign off on that PR
Anyway, I'll claim the two new triage issues today and hopefully get fixes out soon.
@tm - thanks for the concise test cases!

nikomatsakis said:

do you have a sense for whether those 750 cases consist of a few core bugs ?

I suspect it's a few core bugs, but I haven't dug into the issues too much. Reducing a crate to a test case is kind of time consuming, but I'm hoping after fixing a few of them that manual random sampling will give us a sense of whether any are still broken.
yes, that matches my expectation
crater has features for "re-testing" broken tests
which is much faster
so it may behoove you to create a "standing PR"
oh, good to know!
I'm not sure how to make use of those features, I forget how it works, I'm sure @simulacrum or @Pietro Albini could help
there might be docs on forge
The first run took about a week, so I really didn't want to debug by doing a crater run every week and fixing one issue at a time.
https://github.com/rust-lang/crater/blob/master/docs/bot-usage.md#available-crate-selections with a crate selection list -- I can dig up an example
This is probably abusing the PR, but I think I'll spin the individual fixes from #93180 into separate PRs and keep #93180 as the one to enable the feature, then do retests on that.
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/85224#issuecomment-846583774
Okay, let's go ahead and move on from triage
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
The next topic is discussion about progress and blockers on sprint issues
We're short on time, but we can still discuss things if anyone has something they want to bring up.
I imagine there's not a ton to discuss yet since the planning meeting was just a few days ago
Anyway, sounds like there's not much, and we're over time now, so I'll go ahead and close out the meeting.
@triagebot end-meeting

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
Thanks, everyone!
